speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He prays that heaven will bless this marriage so that later times do not reproach them with sorrow. This sets a solemn tone for the secret wedding.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He agrees but says any future sorrow cannot outweigh the joy he gets from seeing Juliet even briefly; he asks the Friar to marry them, and then even death can do its worst, since having her as his own is enough.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He warns that intense joys end violently, like fire and gunpowder exploding when they meet; even sweet things can become sickening if overindulged, so he advises loving moderately because rushing can be as bad as going too slowly.

speaker: JULIET
content: She greets the Friar respectfully as her spiritual advisor.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says Romeo will thank her on behalf of both of them, acknowledging their shared gratitude.

speaker: JULIET
content: She replies that she owes Romeo just as much thanks, otherwise his thanks would be excessive.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He tells Juliet that if her joy is as great as his and she is better at expressing it, she should use her voice to describe the happiness they both feel in seeing each other.

speaker: JULIET
content: She responds that true feeling is richer in substance than in showy words; those who can count their worth are poor, but her love is so immense she cannot tally half its value.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges them to come with him to be married quickly, saying they cannot be left alone until the church has united them as one.
